results.name: Decimal expansion of Sum_{n>=1} (-1)^floor(n*sqrt(2))/n.
comment: If we define the partial sum s_n = Sum_{i=1..n} (-1)^floor(i*sqrt(2))/i then the real-valued sequence s_1, s_2, s_3, ... converges very slowly, and the convergence is not smooth because of the aperiodicity created by the (-1)^floor(i*sqrt(2)) factor. However, if we define the partial sum S_j = s_(n_j) where n_j is the j-th Pell number, then the real-valued sequence S_1, S_2, S_3, ... converges fairly quickly. It appears that, for either even or odd values of j, as j increases, S_j approaches
but the coefficients c1, k1, c2, k2, c3, k3, etc. take one set of values when j is even and a different set of values when j is odd.

E.g., if we use D=10 (or more), and if each of the values t_j is computed with a little more than 100 digits of precision, then c0 = -0.51541845582541799... can be obtained to 100 digits of precision by applying simple numerical methods to accelerate the convergence of the 21 values t_1, t_2, ..., t_21.
